title: Acid-Base Theories
description: Explore different theories that define acids and bases and their applications
subject: Chemistry

text.introduction: Several theories define acids and bases, each with specific applications and limitations. Understanding these theories helps predict chemical behavior and reactions in various systems.

sections.title: Arrhenius Theory
sections.content: Svante Arrhenius defined acids as substances that produce H+ ions in aqueous solution and bases as substances that produce OH- ions. This theory explains many common acids (HCl, H2SO4) and bases (NaOH, Ca(OH)2) but is limited to aqueous solutions and doesn't explain all acid-base behavior.

sections.title: Brønsted-Lowry Theory
sections.content: Johannes Brønsted and Thomas Lowry defined acids as proton (H+) donors and bases as proton acceptors. This theory is broader than Arrhenius theory and explains acid-base reactions in non-aqueous systems. It introduces the concept of conjugate acid-base pairs, where every acid has a conjugate base and vice versa.

sections.title: Lewis Theory
sections.content: Gilbert Lewis defined acids as electron pair acceptors and bases as electron pair donors. This is the broadest definition and includes substances not covered by other theories. Lewis acids often have incomplete octets (like BF3) or can expand their octets (like AlCl3), while Lewis bases have lone pairs of electrons.

sections.title: Applications and Comparisons
sections.content: Each theory has specific applications: Arrhenius for simple aqueous solutions, Brønsted-Lowry for proton transfer reactions and buffer systems, and Lewis for coordination compounds and organic reactions. Understanding when to apply each theory is crucial for predicting and explaining chemical behavior.

questions.question: According to Brønsted-Lowry theory, what is the conjugate base of H2SO4?
questions.explanation: When H2SO4 donates a proton (H+), it forms HSO4⁻, which is its conjugate base.

questions.question: Which theory would best explain the reaction: BF3 + NH3 → F3B-NH3?
questions.explanation: This is a Lewis acid-base reaction where BF3 (electron pair acceptor) reacts with NH3 (electron pair donor).

exercises.title: Acid-Base Theory Application
exercises.instructions: Identify the acids and bases in the following reactions according to each theory: (a) HCl + H2O → H3O+ + Cl⁻, (b) NH3 + H2O ⇌ NH4+ + OH⁻, (c) AlCl3 + Cl⁻ → AlCl4⁻
exercises.hint: Consider which particles donate/accept protons (Brønsted-Lowry) or electrons (Lewis), and which produce H+/OH⁻ ions (Arrhenius).

scenarioChallenges.title: Traditional Medicine and Natural Acids/Bases in Ghana
scenarioChallenges.scenario: Ghana has a rich tradition of using plant-based medicines, many of which contain natural acids and bases. Understanding acid-base chemistry helps explain their effectiveness and safety.
tasks: Explain how citric acid in lime (used in traditional remedies) acts according to different acid-base theories
Describe how alkaloids in medicinal plants function as Brønsted-Lowry bases
Analyze why certain plant preparations need to be diluted or mixed with other substances for safety
learningObjectives: Apply acid-base theories to natural systems
Understand the chemical basis of traditional medicine
Connect modern chemistry to traditional practices
scenarioChallenges.ghanaContext: Ghana has over 3,000 plant species used in traditional medicine, many containing compounds that exhibit acid-base properties.
